I’m amazed by the number of people I talk to who never heard of #ChatGPT. Every time I then show some of its capabilities, people are amazed, then move to anxiety.

Yes, it does push us to rethink a number of things, one comes top of mind: how we educate our kids must change.

Yes, #ChatGPT is very good at synthesising other people's content, but it is no substitute for the political, historical, cultural or geographic smarts needed to win and hold the customer's attention, or to anticipate possible outcomes.

Using #ChatGPT to generate short form reports of current events will only reinforce the tendency toward descriptive analysis. This has limited value for intelligence customers and explains why Western policies are almost always reactive in nature.
Using #ChatGPT to write Google "queries" is no feat of science. Uncertainty is iterative and impossible for a computer program to fully resolve (if in doubt, read Asimov's "The Last Question").
#ChatGPT is the epitome of what people want Siri, Alexa & Google Assistant to grow up and become.

In short, #ChatGPT has the potential to make a competent student more productive, but I am skeptical as to whether it'll allow less competent students to write better term papers.

#ChatGPT made up the following reference: "Negative Campaigning and Voter Turnout: A Natural Experiment in the 2009 German Bundestag Elections" by Ansolabehere, Stephen, et al. in the American Journal of Political Science

Yes, it'll provide you with some references and short summaries thereof on any topic, but #ChatGPT won't/can't write a whole lit review for you. It's a cool tool for literature searches but only alongside your library or Google scholar search or https://t.co/fNleuc4OPF.

Talking to #ChatGPT felt like an office hour with a semi-smart student. It understood most, but not all, of what I wanted them to do and delivered solid but not outstanding results. And it was constantly satisficing.

OK, so I just tried to get #ChatGPT to help me with writing a grant application. In light of the results, all the talk about computer-generated research papers or student term papers seems pretty hyperbole to me. I guess it'll be another few years until we get even close. 🧵

I have been reading a lot of thoughts, insights and points of view on using ChatGPT and AI for content generation over the last few weeks. I genuinely find most of the use cases intriguing and something that's going to evolve over a number of months/years to come.

#ChatGPT #AI

I wouldn’t bet on simply bigger models solving everything, seeing how very simple examples throw #chatgpt off (and because as an academic, I would love there to be something more to it) ;)

Indeed, #chatgpt for example seems to lack any basic sense of logic (see my collection of examples below). So far, it's a bit like Tesla's autopilot with which you have to keep your hands on wheel (or so I think, I'm far from owning a Tesla lol). So it’s almost a bit dangerous,

RT 🐘: Are we in the uncanny valley of large language models? LLMs on which #Chatgpt for instance relies generate compelling and fluid text that one definitely wants to rely on. However, in many tasks of interest this text cannot and SHOULD NOT be relied on without sanity checks.

💡 The bottom line
As with any technology, OpenAI’s #ChatGPT tool has its limits - but its potential is also huge. It’s only been out in the world for about ten days so we can expect any inconsistencies and bugs to be ironed out as it moves forward.

👎 The bad
#ChatGPT doesn’t have any knowledge of things that happened after 2021, which makes some of its suggestions a little out of date.

📈 The figures
-Less than a week after launching, #ChatGPT had over 1 million users. It’s currently free to use, but OpenAI CEO, Sam Altman ( @sama ), said they’ll need to monetise the #tech at some point.

Hence, #ChatGPT poses fundamental questions about what uni education (at least in social sciences) should achieve. If we think that what we teach is right, we have to change assessment forms. Alternatively, we keep them, but reinvent what we teach & expect from students. (8/8)

Most used assessment forms from essays over term papers to theses & dissertations rely on long narrative parts, often presenting arguments against each other or recaping concepts. #ChatGPT is very good in describing concepts and it makes up arguments - some good, som bad. (2/8)

I read & hear a lot of people saying that #ChatGPT often produces texts that sound nice but can be distinguished from good student essays if you look closely. That's probably right. But it does not solve the problem social sciences (and other disciplines) are facing... 🧵(1/8)
